code: library(vivainsights) library(tidyverse) # You may also just load dplyr  clean_spq <-   raw_wowa %>% # Loaded in as a Ways of Working query   identify_nkw(collab_threshold = 4.99999, return = "data_cleaned") %>% # >= 5 CH   identify_inactiveweeks(sd = 2, return = "data_cleaned") %>% # 2 SD   filter(Date >= as.Date("08/30/2020", "%m/%d/%Y")) %>% # Trim start date   filter(Date <= as.Date("03/07/2021", "%m/%d/%Y")) %>% # Trim end date   filter(Date != as.Date("11/22/2020", "%m/%d/%Y")) # Remove certain weeks

what: 8. When you’ve written the same code 3 times, write a function
title: Best Practices: working with Viva Insights in R
text: “best practice” suggestion actually came popular tweet Data Scientist R educator David Robinson. basically captures DRY (Don’t Repeat ) principle programming. several advantages writing functions, one includes fact can just change function , changes applied everywhere script function used. Just consider following example: versus following: second chunk much readable, much easier edit, also elegant first approach explicitly coding everything.
code: # Filter Organization by Sales and extract number of distinct people pq_df %>% filter(Organization == "Sales") %>% pull(PersonId) %>% n_distinct()  # Filter Organization by Operations and extract number of distinct people pq_df %>% filter(Organization == "Operations") %>% pull(PersonId) %>% n_distinct()  # Filter Organization by Engineering and extract number of distinct people pq_df %>% filter(Organization == "Engineering") %>% pull(PersonId) %>% n_distinct() filt_org <- function(filter_string){   pq_df %>% filter(Organization == filter_string) %>% pull(PersonId) %>% n_distinct() }  filt_org("Sales") filt_org("Operations") filt_org("Engineering")

what: Step 2: Generate the igraph network object
title: Plotting a Network Graph using network_g2g
text: network_g2g() function constructs network graph based collaboration data. set: primary secondary define connection points metric specify weight relationships return = "network" get igraph object
code: g <- network_g2g(     data = g2g_data,     primary = "PrimaryCollaborator_Organization",     secondary = "SecondaryCollaborator_Organization",     metric = "Group_meeting_time_invested",      return = "network" )

what: Step 3: Prepare and customize the graph for visualization
title: Plotting a Network Graph using network_g2g
text: plotting, refine graph : Removing loops (self-connections) multiple edges (redundant links) Setting vertex sizes based “org_size” attribute Defining layout using Multidimensional Scaling (MDS)
code: # Simplify the graph (remove redundant edges and self-loops) g <- simplify(g, remove.multiple = TRUE, remove.loops = TRUE)  # Scale node size based on organizational size V(g)$size <- V(g)$org_size    # Generate the MDS layout for better visual clarity layout_mds <- layout_with_mds(g)

what: Step 4: Customize and plot the network graph
title: Plotting a Network Graph using network_g2g
text: set vertex edge properties better readability: Vertex color → blue Edge color → grey Vertex labels → organization names Edge width → fixed 2 clarity Transparency (alpha) edges (adjusted manually)
code: # Example: Assign colors based on an attribute (assuming 'group' exists in V(g)) unique_groups <- unique(V(g)$group)   color_palette <- rainbow(length(unique_groups))  # Generate distinct colors  # Assign colors based on group vertex_color <- color_palette[as.numeric(factor(V(g)$group))]  # Use a color gradient from the 'Blues' palette vertex_color <- colorRampPalette(brewer.pal(9, "Blues"))(length(V(g)))  # Assign colors based on scaled size values vertex_color <- vertex_color[rank(V(g)$size)]  set.seed(123)  # For reproducibility vertex_color <- sample(colors(), length(V(g)), replace = TRUE)  # Define vertex and edge attributes #vertex_color <- "blue"  # Set all vertices to blue edge_color <- "grey"    # Set all edges to grey vertex_labels <- V(g)$name  # Use vertex names as labels  # Plot the graph with customized settings plot(   g,   layout = layout_mds,           # Use the MDS layout   vertex.color = vertex_color,   # Set vertex colors   vertex.label = vertex_labels,  # Assign labels   vertex.frame.color = "black",  # Define frame color for vertices   vertex.size = V(g)$size,       # Scale vertex size   edge.color = edge_color,       # Set edge colors   edge.width = 2,                # Define edge width   edge.alpha = 0.5,              # Adjust transparency (workaround)   vertex.label.dist = 4          # Control label positioning )

what: Step 5: Visualizing the Network Graph using ggplot2
title: Plotting a Network Graph using network_g2g
text: Instead using base plot() function, can leverage ggplot2 along ggraph refined customizable visualization.  final plot displays network collaborations based meeting time invested different organizations.
code: # Convert the igraph object into a dataframe for plotting edges_df <- as_data_frame(g, what = "edges") vertices_df <- as_data_frame(g, what = "vertices")  # Generate Layout (MDS) layout_mds <- layout_with_mds(g) vertices_df$x <- layout_mds[, 1] vertices_df$y <- layout_mds[, 2]  vertices_df$color <- viridis::viridis(n = nrow(vertices_df), option = "C")  ggraph(g, layout = "mds") +   geom_edge_link(aes(edge_alpha = 0.5), color = "grey", width = 2) +     geom_node_point(aes(size = size, color = size)) +   geom_node_text(aes(label = name), vjust = 2, size = 2) +     scale_color_viridis_c() +   theme_minimal() +   labs(title = "Collaboration Network Graph", subtitle = "Using ggplot2 and ggraph") +   theme(panel.grid = element_blank(),          axis.title = element_blank(),          axis.text = element_blank(),          axis.ticks = element_blank())

what: Step 2: Generate the igraph network object
title: Plotting a Network Graph using network_p2p
text: network_p2p() function constructs network graph based collaboration data. set: data simulated P2P dataset hrvar define grouping attribute return = "network" get igraph object
code: g <- network_p2p(   data = p2p_data_sim(),    hrvar = hrvar_text,    return = "network")  # Ensure g is an igraph object if (!inherits(g, "igraph")) {   stop("network_p2p did not return an igraph object. Check function parameters.") }

what: Step 3: Prepare and customize the graph for visualization
title: Plotting a Network Graph using network_p2p
text: plotting, refine graph : Removing loops (self-connections) multiple edges (redundant links) Extracting unique values color mapping Assigning colors scaling node sizes
code: # Simplify the graph (remove redundant edges and self-loops) g <- simplify(g, remove.multiple = TRUE, remove.loops = TRUE)  # Extract unique values for color mapping unique_values <- unique(V(g)$Organization) num_unique_values <- length(unique_values)  # Generate a color palette colors <- brewer.pal(min(num_unique_values, 8), "Set2") org_to_color <- setNames(colors, unique_values)  # Assign colors and scale node sizes V(g)$node_color <- org_to_color[V(g)$Organization] V(g)$node_size <- V(g)$node_size * 120  # Ensure this attribute exists

what: Step 4: Customize and plot the network graph
title: Plotting a Network Graph using network_p2p
text: use ggraph create visually appealing graph : Edge color → blue Vertex color → mapped organization groups Vertex size → scaled according node_size Theme adjustments dark background enhanced readability  final plot displays network peer--peer collaborations based organization groupings, using structured aesthetically refined visualization.
code: ggraph(g, layout = "mds") +   geom_edge_link(aes(edge_alpha = 0.3), color = "#1f78b4") +   geom_node_point(aes(size = V(g)$node_size, color = factor(V(g)$Organization))) +     scale_color_manual(values = org_to_color) +     theme_minimal(base_family = "sans") +  # Use a generic, available font   theme(     plot.background = element_rect(fill = "white", color = NA),     panel.grid = element_blank(),       legend.text = element_text(size = 10, color = "black"),     legend.background = element_rect(fill = "white"),     legend.key = element_rect(fill = "white")   ) +   guides(color = guide_legend(override.aes = list(size = 5)), size = FALSE) ## Warning: The `<scale>` argument of `guides()` cannot be `FALSE`. Use "none" instead as ## of ggplot2 3.3.4. ## This warning is displayed once per session. ## Call `lifecycle::last_lifecycle_warnings()` to see where this warning was ## generated.

title: Identifying noteworthy groups with rank functions
text: get started, let’s open new session R load vivainsights R package. also use dplyr facilitate data manipulation: use pq_data demo dataset, contains weekly person query output, apply collaboration_rank() function: output table contains results automatic group exploration. rank function taken available organisational attributes dataset (FunctionType, Organization, LevelDesignation, IsActive) calculated average collaboration hours group within organisational attribute. table shows analysed results groups, ranked highest lowest. view entire table, can add function print command . analysis shows us 82 employees labelled "FunctionType = "Sales" highest collaboration hours, weekly average 31 hours. second place, 60 individuals Organization = "Inventory Management" 26.2 hours. lower end, 75 employees labelled Organization = "Biz Dev" appear lowest collaboration time. output useful identify groups worth investigating (e.g. employees labelled "FunctionType = Sales"). also reveals splits FunctionType Organization interesting LevelDesignation, variation; groups LevelDesignation similar levels collaboration, 18 22 hours week. title: Information Value analysis with the **vivainsights** R library
text: Information Value (IV) powerful methodology provides measure predictive power individual independent variable relation dependent variable. context Viva Insights, independent variables collaboration metric (e.g. Emails sent, 1:1 meeting time managers), whereas dependent variable categorical variable indicating whether person engaged, top performer, risk attrition - likely provided survey. IV quantifies amount information variable provides outcome. based following logic: variable highly informative outcome different distributions values different outcome classes. example, predicting employee engagement, variable like collaboration hours might different distribution engaged non-engaged classes, indicating informative outcome. IV calculated potential predictor variable, variables ranked based IVs. allows selection predictive variables use model. IV methodology solves problem selecting predictive variables predictive model. ranking variables based IVs, allows selection variables informative outcome, improving predictive power model. also helps identifying excluding variables predictive outcome, can improve model performance interpretability.

title: Information Value analysis with the **vivainsights** R library

title: Information Value analysis with the **vivainsights** R library
text: run IV methodology, binary dependent variable required. can simulate variable following, example can name variable IsLargeNetwork: can define list predictors, assign predictor_list. shown , create_IV() primary function analyzing visualizing Information Value selected outcome variable. use predictors argument supply list predictors, outcome specify varible use dependent variable. return, specify plot returned:  ’s general guideline interpret IV values: IV < 0.02: predictor useful modeling (predictive power). 0.02 <= IV < 0.1: predictor weak predictive power. 0.1 <= IV < 0.3: predictor medium predictive power. 0.3 <= IV < 0.5: predictor strong predictive power. IV >= 0.5: predictor suspiciously high predictive power, may potentially indicate overfitting. just guidelines thresholds can vary depending context specific problem ’re working . real data, always consider business context use judgement interpreting IV values.
code: pq_data$IsLargeNetwork <- ifelse(pq_data$Internal_network_size > 40, 1, 0) predictor_list <- c(   "Email_hours",   "Chat_hours",   "Meeting_hours",   "After_hours_collaboration_hours",   "Multitasking_hours",   "Meeting_and_call_hours_with_manager_1_1" )  create_IV(   pq_data,   predictors = predictor_list,   outcome = "IsLargeNetwork",   return = "plot" )

title: Information Value analysis with the **vivainsights** R library
text: total, five return options can supplied create_IV(), via return: “plot” “summary” “list” “plot-WOE” “IV” shows results return = 'summary', returns DataFrame containing one row per predictor associated IV: ’s also possible return Weight Evidence (WoE) plot . WoE given interval calculated natural logarithm proportion positive outcomes proportion negative outcomes. words, measures evidence favor particular outcome given value independent variable. output return = 'plot-WOE':       ’s also possible return detailed outputs behind calculations return = 'plot-WOE'. return = 'IV', list three items returned. first item list output dictionary data frames contain information WOE, IV, probabilities. second item list output DataFrame IV , identical output return = 'summary'. third item list output natural log odds. can extract follows: guide interpreting WoE, odds, probabilities: positive WoE value indicates odds event higher group question entire dataset. words, event likely occur group. negative WoE value indicates odds event lower group question entire dataset. words, event less likely occur group. WoE zero indicates odds event group entire dataset. Odds: odds event occurring ratio probability event occurring probability event occurring. Probability: likelihood event occurring, value 0 1. return dictionary DataFrames, can also run return = 'list', returns identical dictionary:
code: create_IV(   pq_data,   predictors = predictor_list,   outcome = "IsLargeNetwork",   return = "summary" ) ##                                  Variable       IV ## 1                             Email_hours 1.289015 ## 2                              Chat_hours 1.289015 ## 3                           Meeting_hours 1.289015 ## 4         After_hours_collaboration_hours 1.289015 ## 5                      Multitasking_hours 1.289015 ## [[4]] ##  ## [[5]] ##  ## [[6]] result_iv <- create_IV(                 pq_data,                 predictors = predictor_list,                 outcome = "IsLargeNetwork",                 return = "IV"               ) result_iv[[1]]$Email_hours ## text: Running network visualization Person--person query similar. code , start generating person--person data frame using p2p_data_sim() function. function generates simulated data frame compatible network_p2p() function. text: One additional functionality network_p2p() ability generate centrality statistics. Centrality statistics set metrics used identify important nodes network. following code generates centrality table, table centrality statistics node network. also possible run , averaged attribute specified hrvar argument: definition centrality metrics follows: betweenness: number shortest paths going node. closeness: number steps required access every node given node. degree: number connections linked node. eigenvector: measure influence node network. pagerank: calculates PageRank specified vertices. Please refer igraph package documentation detailed technical definition.

title: Introduction to Organizational Network Analysis with vivainsights in R
text: context ONA, community detection refers process identifying groups nodes (case, individuals within organization) densely connected rest network. groups, communities, often reveal substructures within organization, informal groups teams collaborate across department, job roles, geographical boundaries. Community detection can provide valuable insights structure dynamics organization. example, can help identify silos within organization, information resources might flowing efficiently. can also help identify key individuals serve bridges different communities, leveraged improve communication collaboration across organization. can use community comm_args argument network_p2p() perform community detection. example also specify function use “ggraph” style:  , using Leiden algorithm detect communities. resolution parameter tuning parameter controls size communities. higher value resolution result smaller () communities. network_p2p() operates top community detection algorithms offered igraph package, following algorithms supported: leiden (igraph::cluster_leiden()): Leiden algorithm Traag, van Eck, & Waltman walktrap (igraph::cluster_walktrap()): Walktrap community finding algorithm using short random walks, Pons Latapy fast_greedy (igraph::cluster_fast_greedy()): Fast greedy modularity optimization, Clauset, Newman, & Moore edge_betweenness (igraph::cluster_edge_betweenness()): Edge betweenness community finding algorithm, Girvan & Newman infomap (igraph::cluster_infomap()): Infomap community finding algorithm, Rosvall & Bergstrom label_prop (igraph::cluster_label_prop()): Label propagation community finding algorithm, Raghavan, Albert, & Kumara leading_eigen (igraph::cluster_leading_eigen()): Leading eigenvector community finding algorithm, Newman multilevel (igraph::cluster_multilevel()): Multilevel community finding algorithm, Blondel et al. spinglass (igraph::cluster_spinglass()): Spinglass community finding algorithm, Reichardt & Bornholdt another example use different community detection algorithm:  Please see original igraph documentation details community detection parameters pass comm_args. can also choose visualize explore communities using options available return. instance, can return sankey visual: table communities, group together HR attribute specified hrvar:
code: network_p2p(    data = p2p_data,    community = "leiden",    style = "ggraph",    comm_args = list("resolution" = 0.1)    ) network_p2p(   data = p2p_data,   style = "ggraph",   community = "fluid_communities",   comm_args = list("no.of.communities" = 5) ) network_p2p(   data = p2p_data,   community = "leiden",   return = "sankey",   comm_args = list("resolution" = 0.1) ) network_p2p(   data = p2p_data,   community = "leiden",   return = "table",   comm_args = list("resolution" = 0.1) ) #> # A tibble: 18 × 3 #>    Organization cluster     n #>    <chr>        <chr>   <int> #>  1 Org A        1           2 #>  2 Org A        2           3 #>  3 Org A        3           2 #>  4 Org B        1           2 #>  5 Org B        2           2 #>  6 Org B        3           3 #>  7 Org C        1           3 #>  8 Org C        2           3 #>  9 Org C        3           2 #> 10 Org D        1           2 #> 11 Org D        2           1 #> 12 Org D        3           2 #> 13 Org E        1           2 #> 14 Org E        2           1 #> 15 Org E        3           2 #> 16 Org F        1           3 #> 17 Org F        2           7 #> 18 Org F        3           8

what: Step 1: load libraries and sample data
title: Running pairwise chi-square tests with the `vivainsights` R library
text: example, use sample pq_data dataset vivainsights package. also use dplyr purrr data manipulation iteration respectively, optionally can just load tidyverse package instead.
code: library(vivainsights) library(dplyr) library(purrr)  sample_data <- pq_data

what: Step 2: simulating a dataset with categorical variables
title: Running pairwise chi-square tests with the `vivainsights` R library
text: next step simulate additional categorical variables sample data. example, create three fake categorical variables: Teams, Regions, Functions. merge variables sample data.
code: # Set random seed for reproducibility set.seed(123)  # Number of unique PersonId in data n_personid <- length(unique(sample_data$PersonId))  # Create fake categorical variables for each PersonId cat_data <- data.frame(   PersonId = unique(sample_data$PersonId),   Teams = sample(c('Team 1', 'Team 2', 'Team 3'), size = n_personid, replace = TRUE),   Regions = sample(c('East', 'South', 'West', 'North'), size = n_personid, replace = TRUE),   Functions = sample(c('HR', 'Finance', 'Operations', 'Sales'), size = n_personid, replace = TRUE) )  # Merge the datasets sample_data_merged <- merge(sample_data, cat_data, by = "PersonId")  # Assign categorical variables names to `cat_vars`, alongside existing variables cat_vars <- c("Teams", "Regions", "Functions", "Organization", "LevelDesignation")

what: Step 3: Perform pairwise chi-square tests for all categorical variables
title: Running pairwise chi-square tests with the `vivainsights` R library
text: following, first use combn() generate combinations variable pairs. combn() comes utils package, generates combinations vector elements given size. , set m = 2 yield pairs. Next, use map_dfr() purrr package loop combination perform chi-square test. operation similar loop, results row-bound (similar rbind() bind_rows()) returned data frame. R, generally efficient use map() functions purrr package use loops. Towards end code, add significance level results based p-value. significance level denoted asterisks, *** indicates p < 0.001, ** indicates p < 0.01, * indicates p < 0.05. Finally, can export results csv clipboard using following code:
code: # Generate all combinations of variable pairs cat_var_combinations <- combn(x = cat_vars, m = 2, simplify = FALSE)  # Use `map_dfr()` to loop over each combination results_df <-   map_dfr(cat_var_combinations, ~{   var1 <- .x[1]   var2 <- .x[2]      # Create a contingency table   contingency_table <- table(sample_data_merged[[var1]], sample_data_merged[[var2]])      # Perform chi-square test   chi_test <- chisq.test(contingency_table)      # Return data frame with results   tibble(     var1 = var1,     var2 = var2,     chi2 = chi_test$statistic,     p = chi_test$p.value,     n = sum(contingency_table)   ) %>%     # Add significance level     mutate(       significance = case_when(         p < 0.001 ~ "***",         p < 0.01 ~ "**",         p < 0.05 ~ "*",         TRUE ~ ""     )) })  print(results_df) ## # A tibble: 10 × 6 ##    var1         var2              chi2         p     n significance ##    <chr>        <chr>            <dbl>     <dbl> <int> <chr>        ##  1 Teams        Regions          186.  1.98e- 37  6900 ***          ##  2 Teams        Functions         69.7 4.69e- 13  6900 ***          ##  3 Teams        Organization     325.  3.19e- 62  6900 ***          ##  4 Teams        LevelDesignation 127.  6.93e- 25  6900 ***          ##  5 Regions      Functions        243.  2.39e- 47  6900 ***          ##  6 Regions      Organization     306.  2.93e- 54  6900 ***          ##  7 Regions      LevelDesignation 145.  7.75e- 27  6900 ***          ##  8 Functions    Organization     277.  2.14e- 48  6900 ***          ##  9 Functions    LevelDesignation  92.8 4.43e- 16  6900 ***          ## 10 Organization LevelDesignation 835.  1.40e-165  6900 *** # Copy to clipboard results_df %>% export(method = "clipboard")  # Export to csv results_df %>% export(method = "csv", path = "chi-square-results", timestamp = FALSE)

CSV file can opened Excel. like export list data frames Excel () data frame list corresponds Worksheet (ii) name list member corresponds Sheet name, can use writexl::write_xlsx(). vivainsights depend functions writexl, may need load install separately.

what: How do I filter by specific date ranges?
title: Frequently Asked Questions
text: recommend using dplyr (loaded part tidyverse) data manipulation. filter specific date range Person Query, can run: example filters date range week commencing 30th August 2024 week ending 19th November 2024 inclusive. Note first date Sunday (beginning week) second date Saturday (end week). query run day, specify filter exact last day, rather Saturday week. scenarios, may also want exclude particular week data. can use similar approach: line code excludes week 22nd November 2024, using operator != denote equal . Conversely, can isolate single week replacing != ==.
code: library(vivainsights) library(tidyverse) # Or load dplyr separately  # Read a Person Query from local directory # Assign it to `raw_pq` raw_pq <- import_query("data/person query.csv")  # Assign filtered data frame to `clean_pq` clean_pq <-     raw_pq %>%     filter(Date >= as.Date("08/30/2024", "%m/%d/%Y")) %>%     filter(Date <= as.Date("12/19/2024", "%m/%d/%Y")) clean_pq2 <-     clean_pq %>%     filter(Date != as.Date("11/22/2024", "%m/%d/%Y"))

what: How do I create a custom HR variable?
title: Frequently Asked Questions
text: common way create ‘custom HR variable’ create categorical variable one numeric variables. may want trying bin numeric variable create custom rule-based segmentation Viva Insights metrics. example create categorical variable (N_DirectReports_NET) numeric variable representing number direct reports, using dplyr::mutate() dplyr::case_when() . dplyr::mutate() creates new column, whereas dplyr::case_when() runs -else operation classify numeric ranges right hand side ~ symbol. expression left hand side evaluates TRUE, value right hand side assigned new column. end code, see anything doesn’t get classified gets ‘error handling’ value. value ends “classified”, check whether may gaps dplyr::case_when() chunk capturing values. created new variable checked classifications correct, can analysis using HR attribute, :
code: library(vivainsights) library(tidyverse) # Or load dplyr  clean_pq_with_new_var <-   clean_pq %>% # Standard Person Query   mutate(N_DirectReports_NET =          case_when(NumberofDirectReports == 0 ~ "0",                    NumberofDirectReports == 1 ~ "1",                    NumberofDirectReports <= 5 ~ "2 to 5",                    NumberofDirectReports <= 10 ~ "6 to 10",                    NumberofDirectReports <= 20 ~ "Up to 20",                    NumberofDirectReports >= 21 ~ "21 +",                    TRUE ~ "Not classified")) clean_pq_with_new_var %>%     keymetrics_scan(hrvar = "N_DirectReports_NET")

what: Generate a Information Value HTML Report — IV_report
title: Generate a Information Value HTML Report — IV_report
text: function generates interactive HTML report using Standard Person Query data input. report contains full Information Value analysis,  data exploration technique helps determine columns data set predictive power influence value specified dependent variable.

code: IV_report(   data,   predictors = NULL,   outcome,   bins = 5,   max_var = 9,   path = "IV report",   timestamp = TRUE )

title: Generate a Information Value HTML Report — IV_report
text: data Standard Person Query dataset form data frame. predictors character vector specifying columns used predictors. Defaults NULL, numeric vectors data used predictors. outcome string specifying binary variable, .e. can contain values 1 0. bins Number bins use Information::create_infotables(), defaults 10. max_var Numeric value represent maximum number variables show plots. path Pass file path desired file name, excluding file extension. example, "IV report". timestamp Logical vector specifying whether include timestamp file name. Defaults TRUE.

title: Generate a Information Value HTML Report — IV_report
text: HTML report file name specified arguments generated working directory. outputs directly returned function.

title: Generate a Information Value HTML Report — IV_report
text: example run report.
code: library(dplyr)  pq_data %>%   mutate(CH_binary = ifelse(Collaboration_hours > 12, 1, 0)) %>% # Simulate binary variable   IV_report(outcome =  "CH_binary",             predictors = c("Email_hours", "Meeting_hours"))

what: Compute Information Value for Predictive Variables — create_IV
title: Compute Information Value for Predictive Variables — create_IV
text: function calculates Information Value (IV) selected numeric predictor variables dataset, given specified outcome variable. Information Value provides measure predictive power variable relation outcome variable, can useful feature selection predictive modeling.

title: Compute Information Value for Predictive Variables — create_IV
code: create_IV(   data,   predictors = NULL,   outcome,   bins = 5,   siglevel = 0.05,   exc_sig = FALSE,   return = "plot" )

title: Compute Information Value for Predictive Variables — create_IV
text: data Person Query dataset form data frame. predictors character vector specifying columns used predictors. Defaults NULL, numeric vectors data used predictors. outcome String specifying column name binary variable, containing values 1 0. bins Number bins use, defaults 5. siglevel Significance level use comparing populations outcomes, defaults 0.05 exc_sig Logical value determining whether exclude values p-value lies set siglevel. Defaults FALSE, p-value calculation happen altogether. return String specifying return. must one following strings: "plot" "summary" "list" "plot-WOE" "IV" See Value information.

title: Compute Information Value for Predictive Variables — create_IV
text: different output returned depending value passed return argument: "plot": 'ggplot' object. bar plot showing IV value top (maximum 12) variables. "summary": data frame. summary table metric. "list": list. list outputs input variables. "plot-WOE": list 'ggplot' objects show WOE predictor used model. "IV" returns list object mirrors return Information::create_infotables().

title: Compute Information Value for Predictive Variables — create_IV
text: wrapper around wpa::create_IV().

title: Compute Information Value for Predictive Variables — create_IV
code: # Return a summary table of IV pq_data %>%   dplyr::mutate(X = ifelse(Internal_network_size > 40, 1, 0)) %>%   create_IV(outcome = "X",             predictors = c("Email_hours",                            "Meeting_hours",                            "Chat_hours"),             return = "plot")    # Return summary pq_data %>%   dplyr::mutate(X = ifelse(Internal_network_size > 40, 1, 0)) %>%   create_IV(outcome = "X",             predictors = c("Email_hours", "Meeting_hours"),             return = "summary") #>        Variable       IV #> 1   Email_hours 1.289015 #> 2 Meeting_hours 1.289015

what: Mean Bar Plot for any metric — create_bar
title: Mean Bar Plot for any metric — create_bar
text: Provides overview analysis selected metric calculating mean per metric. Returns bar plot showing average selected metric default. Additional options available return summary table.

title: Mean Bar Plot for any metric — create_bar
code: create_bar(   data,   metric,   hrvar = "Organization",   mingroup = 5,   return = "plot",   bar_colour = "default",   na.rm = FALSE,   percent = FALSE,   plot_title = us_to_space(metric),   plot_subtitle = paste("Average by", tolower(camel_clean(hrvar))),   legend_lab = NULL,   rank = "descending",   xlim = NULL,   text_just = 0.5,   text_colour = "#FFFFFF" )

title: Mean Bar Plot for any metric — create_bar
text: data Standard Person Query dataset form data frame. metric Character string containing name metric, e.g. "Collaboration_hours" hrvar String containing name HR Variable split metrics. Defaults "Organization". run analysis total instead splitting HR attribute, supply NULL (without quotes). mingroup Numeric value setting privacy threshold / minimum group size. Defaults 5. return String specifying return. must one following strings: "plot" "table" See Value information. bar_colour String specify colour use bars. -built accepted values include "default" (default), "alert" (red), "darkblue". Otherwise, hex codes also accepted. can also supply RGB values via rgb2hex(). na.rm logical value indicating whether NA stripped computation proceeds. Defaults FALSE. percent Logical value determine whether show labels percentage signs. Defaults FALSE. plot_title option override plot title. plot_subtitle option override plot subtitle. legend_lab String. Option override legend title/label. Defaults NULL, metric name populated instead. rank String specifying rank bars. Valid inputs : "descending" - ranked highest lowest top bottom (default). "ascending" - ranked lowest highest top bottom. NULL - uses original levels HR attribute. xlim option set max value x axis. text_just numeric value controlling horizontal position text labels. Defaults 0.5. text_colour String specify colour use text labels. Defaults "#FFFFFF".

title: Mean Bar Plot for any metric — create_bar
text: different output returned depending value passed return argument: "plot": 'ggplot' object. bar plot metric. "table": data frame. summary table metric.

title: Mean Bar Plot for any metric — create_bar
code: # Return a ggplot bar chart create_bar(pq_data, metric = "Collaboration_hours", hrvar = "LevelDesignation")   # Change bar colour create_bar(pq_data,            metric = "After_hours_collaboration_hours",            bar_colour = "alert")   # Custom data label positions and formatting pq_data %>%   create_bar(     metric = "Meetings",     text_just = 1.1,     text_colour = "black",     xlim = 20)   # Return a summary table create_bar(pq_data,            metric = "Collaboration_hours",            hrvar = "LevelDesignation",            return = "table") #> # A tibble: 4 × 3 #>   group          Collaboration_hours     n #>   <chr>                        <dbl> <int> #> 1 Executive                     23.2    37 #> 2 Junior IC                     22.9   136 #> 3 Senior IC                     23.1    87 #> 4 Senior Manager                22.8    40

what: Create a bar chart without aggregation for any metric — create_bar_asis
title: Create a bar chart without aggregation for any metric — create_bar_asis
text: function creates bar chart directly aggregated / summarised data. Unlike create_bar() performs person-level aggregation, calculation create_bar_asis() values rendered passed function.

title: Create a bar chart without aggregation for any metric — create_bar_asis
code: create_bar_asis(   data,   group_var,   bar_var,   title = NULL,   subtitle = NULL,   caption = NULL,   ylab = group_var,   xlab = bar_var,   percent = FALSE,   bar_colour = "default",   rounding = 1 )

title: Create a bar chart without aggregation for any metric — create_bar_asis
text: data Plotting data data frame. group_var String containing name variable group. bar_var String containing name variable representing value bars. title Title plot. subtitle Subtitle plot. caption Caption plot. ylab Y-axis label plot (group axis) xlab X-axis label plot (bar axis). percent Logical value determine whether show labels percentage signs. Defaults FALSE. bar_colour String specify colour use bars. -built accepted values include "default" (default), "alert" (red), "darkblue". Otherwise, hex codes also accepted. can also supply RGB values via rgb2hex(). rounding Numeric value specify number digits show data labels

title: Create a bar chart without aggregation for any metric — create_bar_asis
text: 'ggplot' object. horizontal bar plot.

title: Create a bar chart without aggregation for any metric — create_bar_asis
code: # Creating a custom bar plot without mean aggregation library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: ‘dplyr’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:stats’: #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’: #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union  pq_data %>%   group_by(Organization) %>%   summarise(across(.cols = Meeting_hours,                    .fns = ~sum(., na.rm = TRUE))) %>%   create_bar_asis(group_var = "Organization",                   bar_var = "Meeting_hours",                   title = "Total Meeting Hours over period",                   subtitle = "By Organization",                   caption = extract_date_range(pq_data, return = "text"),                   bar_colour = "darkblue",                   rounding = 0)   library(dplyr)  # Summarise Non-person-average median `Emails_sent` med_df <-   pq_data %>%   group_by(Organization) %>%   summarise(Emails_sent_median = median(Emails_sent))  med_df %>%   create_bar_asis(     group_var = "Organization",     bar_var = "Emails_sent_median",     title = "Emails sent by organization",     subtitle = "Median values",     bar_colour = "darkblue",     caption = extract_date_range(pq_data, return = "text")   )

what: Box Plot for any metric — create_boxplot
title: Box Plot for any metric — create_boxplot
text: Analyzes selected metric returns box plot default. Additional options available return table distribution elements.

title: Box Plot for any metric — create_boxplot
code: create_boxplot(   data,   metric,   hrvar = "Organization",   mingroup = 5,   return = "plot" )

title: Box Plot for any metric — create_boxplot
text: data Standard Person Query dataset form data frame. metric Character string containing name metric, e.g. "Collaboration_hours" hrvar String containing name HR Variable split metrics. Defaults "Organization". run analysis total instead splitting HR attribute, supply NULL (without quotes). mingroup Numeric value setting privacy threshold / minimum group size. Defaults 5. return String specifying return. must one following strings: "plot" "table" "data" See Value information.

title: Box Plot for any metric — create_boxplot
text: different output returned depending value passed return argument: "plot": 'ggplot' object. box plot metric. "table": data frame. summary table metric, containing following columns: group: HR variable metric split. mean: mean metric. min: minimum value metric. p10: 10th percentile metric. p25: 25th percentile metric. p50: 50th percentile metric. p75: 75th percentile metric. p90: 90th percentile metric. max: maximum value metric. sd: standard deviation metric. range: range metric. n: number observations. "data": data frame. data frame containing metric group.

title: Box Plot for any metric — create_boxplot
text: general purpose function powers functions package produce box plots.

title: Box Plot for any metric — create_boxplot

title: Create a density plot for any metric — create_density
text: data Standard Person Query dataset form data frame. metric String containing name metric, e.g. "Collaboration_hours" hrvar String containing name HR Variable split metrics. Defaults "Organization". run analysis total instead splitting HR attribute, supply NULL (without quotes). mingroup Numeric value setting privacy threshold / minimum group size. Defaults 5. ncol Numeric value setting number columns plot. Defaults NULL (automatic). return String specifying return. must one following strings: "plot" "table" "data" "frequency" See Value information.

title: Create a density plot for any metric — create_density
text: different output returned depending value passed return argument: "plot": 'ggplot' object. faceted density plot metric. "table": data frame. summary table metric, containing following columns: group: HR variable metric split. mean: mean metric. min: minimum value metric. p10: 10th percentile metric. p25: 25th percentile metric. p50: 50th percentile metric. p75: 75th percentile metric. p90: 90th percentile metric. max: maximum value metric. sd: standard deviation metric. range: range metric. n: number observations. "data": data frame. Data calculated person averages. "frequency: list data frames. data frame contains frequencies used panel plotted histogram.

title: Create a density plot for any metric — create_density

what: Horizontal 100 percent stacked bar plot for any metric — create_dist
title: Horizontal 100 percent stacked bar plot for any metric — create_dist
text: Provides analysis distribution selected metric. Returns stacked bar plot default. Additional options available return table distribution elements.

title: Horizontal 100 percent stacked bar plot for any metric — create_dist
code: create_dist(   data,   metric,   hrvar = "Organization",   mingroup = 5,   return = "plot",   cut = c(15, 20, 25),   dist_colours = c("#facebc", "#fcf0eb", "#b4d5dd", "#bfe5ee"),   unit = "hours",   lbound = 0,   ubound = 200,   sort_by = NULL,   labels = NULL )

title: Horizontal 100 percent stacked bar plot for any metric — create_dist
text: data Standard Person Query dataset form data frame. metric String containing name metric, e.g. "Collaboration_hours" hrvar String containing name HR Variable split metrics. Defaults "Organization". run analysis total instead splitting HR attribute, supply NULL (without quotes). mingroup Numeric value setting privacy threshold / minimum group size. Defaults 5. return String specifying return. must one following strings: "plot" "table" See Value information. cut numeric vector length three specify breaks distribution, e.g. c(10, 15, 20) dist_colours character vector length four specify colour codes stacked bars. unit String specify unit use. defaults "hours" can accept custom string. See cut_hour() details. lbound Numeric. Specifies lower bound (inclusive) value minimum label. Defaults 0. ubound Numeric. Specifies upper bound (inclusive) value maximum label. Defaults 100. sort_by String specify bucket label sort . Defaults NULL (sorting). labels Character vector override labels created categorical variables. Must named vector - see examples.

title: Horizontal 100 percent stacked bar plot for any metric — create_dist
text: different output returned depending value passed return argument: "plot": 'ggplot' object. stacked bar plot metric. "table": data frame. summary table metric.

title: Horizontal 100 percent stacked bar plot for any metric — create_dist
code: # Return plot create_dist(pq_data, metric = "Collaboration_hours", hrvar = "Organization")   # Return summary table create_dist(pq_data, metric = "Collaboration_hours", hrvar = "Organization", return = "table") #> # A tibble: 7 × 5 #>   group      `15 - 20 hours` `20 - 25 hours` `25+ hours` Employee_Count #>   <fct>                <dbl>           <dbl>       <dbl>          <int> #> 1 Finance            NA                0.897      0.103              68 #> 2 HR                 NA                1         NA                  33 #> 3 IT                 NA                0.941      0.0588             68 #> 4 Legal               0.0227           0.977     NA                  44 #> 5 Operations          0.0455           0.727      0.227              22 #> 6 Research           NA                0.904      0.0962             52 #> 7 Sales              NA                1         NA                  13  # Use custom labels by providing a label vector eh_labels <- c(   "Fewer than fifteen" = "< 15 hours",   "Between fifteen and twenty" = "15 - 20 hours",   "Between twenty and twenty-five" = "20 - 25 hours",   "More than twenty-five" = "25+ hours" )  pq_data %>% create_dist(metric = "Meeting_hours", labels = eh_labels, return = "plot")   # Sort by a category pq_data %>%  create_dist(metric = "Collaboration_hours", sort_by = "25+ hours")

title: Create an incidence analysis reflecting proportion of population scoring above or below a threshold for a metric — create_inc

what: Estimate an effect of intervention on every Viva Insights metric in input file by applying single-group Interrupted Time-Series Analysis (ITSA) — create_itsa
title: Estimate an effect of intervention on every Viva Insights metric in input file by applying single-group Interrupted Time-Series Analysis (ITSA) — create_itsa
text: r lifecycle::badge('experimental') function implements ITSA method described paper 'Conducting interrupted time-series analysis single- multiple-group comparisons', Ariel Linden, Stata Journal (2015), 15, Number 2, pp. 480-500 function requires installation 'sandwich' 'lmtest' order work. packages can installed CRAN using install.packages().

title: Estimate an effect of intervention on every Viva Insights metric in input file by applying single-group Interrupted Time-Series Analysis (ITSA) — create_itsa
code: create_itsa(   data,   metrics = NULL,   before_start = NULL,   before_end = NULL,   after_start = NULL,   after_end = NULL,   ac_lags_max = 7,   return = "table" )

title: Estimate an effect of intervention on every Viva Insights metric in input file by applying single-group Interrupted Time-Series Analysis (ITSA) — create_itsa
text: data Person Query dataframe including date column named MetricDate. function assumes data format %Y-%m-%d standard Viva Insights query output. metrics character vector containing variable names perform interrupted time series analysis . before_start String specifying start date '' time period %Y-%m-%d format. '' time period refers period intervention (e.g. training program, re-org, shift remote work) occurs bounded before_start before_end parameters. Longer period increases likelihood achieving statistically significant results. Defaults earliest date dataset. provided, defaults earliest date dataset. before_end String specifying end date '' time period %Y-%m-%d format. NULL, error raised, value required. after_start String specifying start date '' time period %Y-%m-%d format. NULL, default value before_end. '' time period refers period intervention occurs bounded after_start after_end parameters. Longer periods increase likelihood achieving statistically significant results. after_end String specifying end date '' time period %Y-%m-%d format. Defaults latest date dataset. ac_lags_max Numeric value specifying maximum lag autocorrelation test. Ljung-Box test used check autocorrelation model residuals specified number lags. Higher values check longer-term dependencies time series data. return String specifying output return. Defaults "table". Valid return options include: 'plot': return list plots. 'table': return data.frame estimated models' coefficients corresponding p-values look significant p-values beta_2 indicate immediate treatment effect, /beta_3 indicate treatment effect time

title: Estimate an effect of intervention on every Viva Insights metric in input file by applying single-group Interrupted Time-Series Analysis (ITSA) — create_itsa
text: 'data' passed return, data frame following columns: metric_name: Name metric analyzed. beta_2: Coefficient immediate treatment effect. beta_3: Coefficient treatment effect time. beta_2_pvalue: P-value immediate treatment effect. beta_3_pvalue: P-value treatment effect time. AR_flag: Logical flag indicating whether autocorrelation detected. error_warning: Error warning message applicable.

title: Estimate an effect of intervention on every Viva Insights metric in input file by applying single-group Interrupted Time-Series Analysis (ITSA) — create_itsa
text: function uses additional package dependencies 'sandwich' 'lmtest'. Please install separately CRAN prior running function. May 2022, 'portes' package archived CRAN. dependency since removed dependent functions Ljungbox() incorporated wpa package.

title: Estimate an effect of intervention on every Viva Insights metric in input file by applying single-group Interrupted Time-Series Analysis (ITSA) — create_itsa
text: Aleksey Ashikhmin alashi@microsoft.com

title: Estimate an effect of intervention on every Viva Insights metric in input file by applying single-group Interrupted Time-Series Analysis (ITSA) — create_itsa
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Returns summary table create_itsa(   data = pq_data,   metrics = c("Collaboration_span", "Internal_network_size"),   before_end = "2024-07-01",   after_start = "2024-07-01",   ac_lags_max = 7,   return = "table" )  # Returns list of plots plot_list <-   create_itsa(     data = pq_data,     metrics = c("Collaboration_span", "Internal_network_size"),     before_end = "2024-07-01",     after_start = "2024-07-01",     ac_lags_max = 7,     return = "plot"   )  # Extract a plot as an example plot_list$Collaboration_span } # }

what: Generate Rogers Adoption Curve plots for Copilot usage — create_rogers
title: Generate Rogers Adoption Curve plots for Copilot usage — create_rogers
text: Creates various visualizations based Rogers adoption curve theory, analyzing adoption patterns Copilot usage. function identifies habitual users using identify_habit() function creates adoption curve visualizations based different time frames organizational groupings.

title: Generate Rogers Adoption Curve plots for Copilot usage — create_rogers
code: create_rogers(   data,   hrvar = NULL,   metric,   width = 9,   max_window = 12,   threshold = 1,   start_metric = NULL,   return = "plot",   plot_mode = 1,   label = FALSE )

title: Generate Rogers Adoption Curve plots for Copilot usage — create_rogers
text: data Data frame containing Person Query data analyzed. Must contain PersonId, MetricDate, specified metrics. hrvar Character string specifying HR attribute organizational variable group . Default NULL, grouping. metric Character string containing name metric analyze habit identification, e.g. "Total_Copilot_actions". passed identify_habit(). width Integer specifying number qualifying counts consider habit. Passed identify_habit(). Default 9. max_window Integer specifying maximum unit dates consider qualifying window habit. Passed identify_habit(). Default 12. threshold Numeric value specifying minimum threshold metric considered qualifying count. Passed identify_habit(). Default 1. start_metric Character string containing name metric used determining enablement start date. metric track users first gained access technology analyzed. function identifies earliest date metric greater 0 user "enablement date". used plot modes 3 4 calculate time--adoption Rogers segment classifications. suggested variable "Total_Copilot_enabled_days", metric indicates access licensing status can used (e.g., "License_assigned_days", "Access_granted"). parameter optional plot modes 1 2, required plot modes 3 4. return = "data" start_metric provided, Rogers segment classifications included returned data frame. Default NULL. return Character vector specifying return. Valid inputs "plot", "data", "table". Default "plot". plot_mode Integer character string determining plot return. Valid inputs : 1 "cumulative": Rogers Adoption Curve showing cumulative adoption 2 "weekly": Weekly Rate adoption showing new habitual users 3 "enablement": Enablement-based adoption rate Rogers segments 4 "cumulative_enablement": Cumulative adoption adjusted enablement Default 1. label Logical value determine whether show data point labels plot cumulative adoption curves (plot modes 1 4). TRUE, geom_point() geom_text() added display data labels rounded 1 decimal place data point. Defaults FALSE.

title: Generate Rogers Adoption Curve plots for Copilot usage — create_rogers
text: Returns 'ggplot' object default 'plot' passed return. 'table' passed, summary table returned data frame. 'data' passed, processed data habit classifications returned. return = "data", returned data frame includes: original columns input data IsHabit: Binary indicator whether user developed habit adoption_week: week user first exhibited habitual behavior enable_week: (start_metric provided) week user first enabled weeks_to_adopt: (start_metric provided) Number weeks enablement adoption RogersSegment: (start_metric provided) Rogers adoption segment classification: "Innovators" (fastest 2.5\ "Early Adopters" (next 13.5\ "Early Majority" (next 34\ "Late Majority" (next 34\ "Laggards" (slowest 16\

title: Generate Rogers Adoption Curve plots for Copilot usage — create_rogers
text: function provides four distinct plot modes analyze adoption patterns: Plot Mode 1 - Cumulative Adoption Curve: Shows classic Rogers adoption curve cumulative percentage habitual users time. S-shaped curve helps identify pace adoption saturation begins. Steep sections indicate rapid adoption periods, flat sections suggest slower uptake natural limits. Plot Mode 2 - Weekly Adoption Rate: Displays number new habitual users identified week, 3-week moving average line smooth volatility. view helps identify adoption spikes, seasonal patterns, natural ebb flow user onboarding. High bars indicate successful onboarding periods. Plot Mode 3 - Enablement-Based Adoption: Analyzes adoption relative users first enabled (access). Users classified Rogers segments (Innovators, Early Adopters, Early/Late Majority, Laggards) based quickly adopted enablement. helps understand natural distribution adoption speed within organization. Plot Mode 4 - Cumulative Enablement-Adjusted: Similar Mode 1 includes users enablement data, providing accurate view adoption among actually access technology. removes noise users may properly enabled. Interpretation Guidelines: Early steep curves suggest strong product-market fit Plateaus may indicate training needs feature limitations Seasonal patterns often reflect organizational training cycles Rogers segments help identify user personas targeted interventions

title: Generate Rogers Adoption Curve plots for Copilot usage — create_rogers
text: Chris Gideon chris.gideon@microsoft.com

title: Generate Rogers Adoption Curve plots for Copilot usage — create_rogers
code: # Basic Rogers adoption curve create_rogers(   data = pq_data,   metric = "Copilot_actions_taken_in_Teams",   plot_mode = 1 ) #> Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0. #> ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead. #> ℹ The deprecated feature was likely used in the vivainsights package. #>   Please report the issue at #>   <https://github.com/microsoft/vivainsights/issues/>.   # Weekly adoption rate by organization create_rogers(   data = pq_data,   hrvar = "Organization",   metric = "Copilot_actions_taken_in_Teams",   plot_mode = 2 ) #> Warning: Removed 14 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_line()`). #> `geom_line()`: Each group consists of only one observation. #> ℹ Do you need to adjust the group aesthetic?   # Enablement-based adoption create_rogers(   data = pq_data,   metric = "Copilot_actions_taken_in_Teams",   start_metric = "Total_Copilot_enabled_days",   plot_mode = 3 )   # Return data with Rogers segments rogers_data <- create_rogers(   data = pq_data,   metric = "Copilot_actions_taken_in_Teams",   start_metric = "Total_Copilot_enabled_days",   return = "data" ) #> Rogers segments calculated based on Total_Copilot_enabled_days #> Total users with Rogers segments: 300  # Rogers adoption curve with data point labels create_rogers(   data = pq_data,   metric = "Copilot_actions_taken_in_Teams",   plot_mode = 1,   label = TRUE )

what: Create a line chart that tracks metrics over time with a 4-week rolling average — create_tracking
title: Create a line chart that tracks metrics over time with a 4-week rolling average — create_tracking
text: Create two-series line chart visualizes set metric time selected population, one series four-week rolling average.

title: Create a line chart that tracks metrics over time with a 4-week rolling average — create_tracking
code: create_tracking(   data,   metric,   plot_title = us_to_space(metric),   plot_subtitle = "Measure over time",   percent = FALSE )

title: Create a line chart that tracks metrics over time with a 4-week rolling average — create_tracking
text: data Standard Person Query dataset form data frame. metric Character string containing name metric, e.g. "Collaboration_hours" percentage signs. Defaults FALSE. plot_title option override plot title. plot_subtitle option override plot subtitle. percent Logical value determine whether show labels percentage signs. Defaults FALSE.

title: Create a line chart that tracks metrics over time with a 4-week rolling average — create_tracking
text: different output returned depending value passed return argument: "plot": 'ggplot' object. time-series plot metric. "table": data frame. summary table metric.

title: Create a line chart that tracks metrics over time with a 4-week rolling average — create_tracking
code: pq_data %>%   create_tracking(     metric = "Collaboration_hours",     percent = FALSE   )

what: Heat mapped horizontal bar plot over time for any metric — create_trend
title: Heat mapped horizontal bar plot over time for any metric — create_trend
text: Provides week week view selected Viva Insights metric. default returns week week heatmap bar plot, highlighting points time activity. Additional options available return summary table.

title: Heat mapped horizontal bar plot over time for any metric — create_trend
code: create_trend(   data,   metric,   hrvar = "Organization",   mingroup = 5,   palette = c("steelblue4", "aliceblue", "white", "mistyrose1", "tomato1"),   return = "plot",   legend_title = "Hours" )

title: Heat mapped horizontal bar plot over time for any metric — create_trend
text: data Standard Person Query dataset form data frame. metric Character string containing name metric, e.g. "Collaboration_hours" hrvar String containing name HR Variable split metrics. Defaults "Organization". run analysis total instead splitting HR attribute, supply NULL (without quotes). mingroup Numeric value setting privacy threshold / minimum group size. Defaults 5. palette Character vector containing colour codes, ranked lowest value highest value. passed directly ggplot2::scale_fill_gradientn(). return Character vector specifying return, defaults "plot". Valid inputs "plot" "table". legend_title String used title legend. Defaults "Hours".

title: Heat mapped horizontal bar plot over time for any metric — create_trend
text: Returns 'ggplot' object default, 'plot' passed return. 'table' passed, summary table returned data frame.

title: Heat mapped horizontal bar plot over time for any metric — create_trend
code: create_trend(pq_data, metric = "Collaboration_hours", hrvar = "LevelDesignation")   # custom colours create_trend(   pq_data,   metric = "Collaboration_hours",   hrvar = "LevelDesignation",   palette = c(     "#FB6107",     "#F3DE2C",     "#7CB518",     "#5C8001"   )   )

what: Convert a numeric variable for hours into categorical — cut_hour
title: Convert a numeric variable for hours into categorical — cut_hour
text: Supply numeric variable, e.g. Collaboration_hours, return character vector.

title: Convert a numeric variable for hours into categorical — cut_hour
code: cut_hour(metric, cuts, unit = "hours", lbound = 0, ubound = 100)

title: Convert a numeric variable for hours into categorical — cut_hour
text: metric numeric variable representing hours. cuts numeric vector minimum length 3 represent cut points required. minimum maximum values provided vector inclusive. unit String specify unit labels. Defaults "hours". lbound Numeric. Specifies lower bound (inclusive) value minimum label. Defaults 0. ubound Numeric. Specifies upper bound (inclusive) value maximum label. Defaults 100.

title: Convert a numeric variable for hours into categorical — cut_hour
text: Character vector representing converted categorical variable, appended label unit. See examples information.

title: Convert a numeric variable for hours into categorical — cut_hour
text: used within create_dist() numeric categorical conversion.

what: Distribution of Email Hours as a 100% stacked bar — email_dist
title: Distribution of Email Hours as a 100% stacked bar — email_dist
text: Analyze Email Hours distribution. Returns stacked bar plot default. Additional options available return table distribution elements.

title: Distribution of Email Hours as a 100% stacked bar — email_dist
code: email_dist(   data,   hrvar = "Organization",   mingroup = 5,   return = "plot",   cut = c(0.5, 1, 1.5) )

title: Distribution of Email Hours as a 100% stacked bar — email_dist
text: data Standard Person Query dataset form data frame. hrvar String containing name HR Variable split metrics. Defaults "Organization". run analysis total instead splitting HR attribute, supply NULL (without quotes). mingroup Numeric value setting privacy threshold / minimum group size. Defaults 5. return String specifying return. must one following strings: "plot" "table" See Value information. cut numeric vector length three specify breaks distribution, e.g. c(10, 15, 20)

title: Distribution of Email Hours as a 100% stacked bar — email_dist
text: different output returned depending value passed return argument: "plot": 'ggplot' object. stacked bar plot metric. "table": data frame. summary table metric.

title: Distribution of Email Hours as a 100% stacked bar — email_dist
code: # Return plot email_dist(pq_data, hrvar = "Organization")   # Return summary table email_dist(pq_data, hrvar = "Organization", return = "table") #> # A tibble: 7 × 3 #>   group      `1.5+ hours` Employee_Count #>   <fct>             <dbl>          <int> #> 1 Finance               1             68 #> 2 HR                    1             33 #> 3 IT                    1             68 #> 4 Legal                 1             44 #> 5 Operations            1             22 #> 6 Research              1             52 #> 7 Sales                 1             13  # Return result with a custom specified breaks email_dist(pq_data, hrvar = "LevelDesignation", cut = c(1, 2, 3))

what: Email Time Trend - Line Chart — email_line
title: Email Time Trend - Line Chart — email_line
text: Provides week week view email time, visualised line charts. default returns line chart email hours, separate panel per value HR attribute. Additional options available return summary table.

title: Email Time Trend - Line Chart — email_line
code: email_line(   data,   hrvar = "Organization",   mingroup = 5,   return = "plot",   label = FALSE )

title: Email Time Trend - Line Chart — email_line
text: data Standard Person Query dataset form data frame. hrvar String containing name HR Variable split metrics. Defaults "Organization". run analysis total instead splitting HR attribute, supply NULL (without quotes). mingroup Numeric value setting privacy threshold / minimum group size. Defaults 5. return String specifying return. must one following strings: "plot" "table" See Value information. label Logical value determine whether show data point labels plot. TRUE, geom_point() geom_text() added display data labels rounded 1 decimal place data point. Defaults FALSE.

title: Email Time Trend - Line Chart — email_line
text: different output returned depending value passed return argument: "plot": 'ggplot' object. faceted line plot metric. "table": data frame. summary table metric.

title: Email Time Trend - Line Chart — email_line

text: x Data frame 'ggplot' object passed . method Character string specifying method export. Valid inputs include: "clipboard" (default input data frame) "csv" "png" (default input 'ggplot' object) "svg" "jpeg" "pdf" path exporting file, enter path desired file name, excluding file extension. example, "Analysis/SQ Overview". timestamp Logical vector specifying whether include timestamp file name. Defaults TRUE. width Width plot height Height plot

title: Export 'vivainsights' outputs to CSV, clipboard, or save as images — export

"png": PNG file containing 'ggplot' object saved specified path. "svg": SVG file containing 'ggplot' object saved specified path. "jpeg": JPEG file containing 'ggplot' object saved specified path. "pdf": PDF file containing 'ggplot' object saved specified path.

title: Flag unusual high collaboration hours to after-hours collaboration hours ratio — flag_ch_ratio
code: flag_ch_ratio(pq_data) #> [Pass] The ratio of after-hours collaboration to total collaboration hours is outside the expected threshold for only 0 employees (0 % of the total). #> - 0 employees (0 %) have an unusually high after-hours collaboration (relative to weekly collaboration hours) #> - 0 employees (0 %) have an unusually low after-hours collaboration   data.frame(PersonId = c("Alice", "Bob"),            Collaboration_hours = c(30, 0.5),            After_hours_collaboration_hours = c(0.5, 30)) %>%   flag_ch_ratio() #> [Warning]  The ratio of after-hours collaboration to total collaboration hours is outside the expected threshold for 2 employees (100 % of the total). #> - 1 employees (50 %) have an unusually high after-hours collaboration (relative to weekly collaboration hours) #> - 1 employees (50 %) have an unusually low after-hours collaboration

title: Warn for extreme values by checking against a threshold — flag_extreme
code: # The threshold values are intentionally set low to trigger messages. flag_extreme(pq_data, "Email_hours", threshold = 15) #> [Pass] There are no persons where their average Email hours exceeds 15.  # Return a summary table flag_extreme(pq_data, "Email_hours", threshold = 15, return = "table") #> # A tibble: 0 × 2 #> # ℹ 2 variables: PersonId <chr>, Email_hours <dbl>  # Person-week level flag_extreme(pq_data, "Email_hours", person = FALSE, threshold = 15) #> [Warning] There are 47 rows where their value of Email hours exceeds 15.  # Check for values equal to threshold flag_extreme(pq_data, "Email_hours", person = TRUE, mode = "equal", threshold = 0) #> [Pass] There are no persons where their average Email hours are equal to 0.  # Check for values below threshold flag_extreme(pq_data, "Email_hours", person = TRUE, mode = "below", threshold = 5) #> [Pass] There are no persons where their average Email hours are less than 5.

what: Generate HTML report based on existing RMarkdown documents — generate_report2
title: Generate HTML report based on existing RMarkdown documents — generate_report2
text: support function accepts parameters creates HTML document based RMarkdown template. alternative generate_report() instead creates RMarkdown document scratch using individual code chunks.

title: Generate HTML report based on existing RMarkdown documents — generate_report2
code: generate_report2(   output_format = rmarkdown::html_document(toc = TRUE, toc_depth = 6, theme = "cosmo"),   output_file = "report.html",   output_dir = getwd(),   report_title = "Report",   rmd_dir = system.file("rmd_template/minimal.rmd", package = "vivainsights"),   ... )

title: Generate HTML report based on existing RMarkdown documents — generate_report2
text: output_format output format rmarkdown::render(). Default rmarkdown::html_document(toc = TRUE, toc_depth = 6, theme = "cosmo"). output_file output file name rmarkdown::render(). Default "report.html". output_dir output directory report rmarkdown::render(). Default user's current directory. report_title report title. Default "Report". rmd_dir string specifying path directory containing RMarkdown template files. ... arguments passed params. instance, pass hrvar RMarkdown document requires 'hrvar' parameter.

title: Generate HTML report based on existing RMarkdown documents — generate_report2
text: implementation function inspired 'DataExplorer' package boxuancui, credits due original author.

what: Identify employees who have churned from the dataset — identify_churn
title: Identify employees who have churned from the dataset — identify_churn
text: function identifies counts number employees churned dataset measuring whether employee present first n (n1) weeks data present last n (n2) weeks data.

title: Identify employees who have churned from the dataset — identify_churn
code: identify_churn(data, n1 = 6, n2 = 6, return = "message", flip = FALSE)

title: Identify employees who have churned from the dataset — identify_churn
text: data Person Query data frame. Must contain PersonId. n1 numeric value specifying number weeks beginning period defines measured employee set. Defaults 6. n2 numeric value specifying number weeks end period calculate whether employees churned data. Defaults 6. return String specifying return. must one following strings: "message" (default) "text" "data" See Value information. flip Logical, defaults FALSE. determines whether reverse logic identifying non-overlapping set. set TRUE, effectively identifies new-joiners, present first n weeks data present final n weeks.

title: Identify employees who have churned from the dataset — identify_churn
text: different output returned depending value passed return argument: "message": Message console. diagnostic message. "text": String. diagnostic message. "data": Character vector containing PersonId employees identified churned.

title: Identify employees who have churned from the dataset — identify_churn
text: additional use case function ability identify "new-joiners" using argument flip. employee present first n weeks data present last n weeks data, function considers employee churned. measurement period defined number weeks start end passed data frame, may consider filtering dates accordingly running function. Another assumption place employee whose PersonId available data churned. Note may reasons employee's PersonId may present, e.g. maternity/paternity leave, Viva Insights license removed, shift low-collaboration role (extent /becomes inactive).

title: Identify employees who have churned from the dataset — identify_churn
code: pq_data %>% identify_churn(n1 = 3, n2 = 3, return = "message") #> Churn: #> There are 0 employees from 2024-04-28 to 2024-05-12 (3 weeks) who are no longer present in 2024-09-15 to 2024-09-29 (3 weeks).

what: Identify date frequency based on a series of dates — identify_datefreq
title: Identify date frequency based on a series of dates — identify_datefreq
text: Takes vector dates identify whether frequency 'daily', 'weekly', 'monthly'. primary use case function provide accurate description query type used raising errors wrong date grouping used data input.

title: Identify date frequency based on a series of dates — identify_datefreq
code: identify_datefreq(x)

title: Identify date frequency based on a series of dates — identify_datefreq
text: x Vector containing series dates.

title: Identify date frequency based on a series of dates — identify_datefreq
text: String describing detected date frequency, .e.: 'daily' 'weekly' 'monthly'

title: Identify date frequency based on a series of dates — identify_datefreq
text: Date frequency detection works follows: least three days week present (e.g., Monday, Wednesday, Thursday) series, series classified 'daily' total number months series equal length, series classified 'monthly' total number sundays series equal length series, series classified 'weekly

title: Identify date frequency based on a series of dates — identify_datefreq
text: One assumptions made behind classification weeks denoted Sundays, hence count sundays measure number weeks. case, weeks Sunday missing result 'unable classify' error. Another assumption made dates evenly distributed, .e. gap dates equal. dates unevenly distributed, e.g. two days week available given week, algorithm fail identify frequency 'daily'.

title: Identify date frequency based on a series of dates — identify_datefreq
code: start_date <- as.Date("2022/06/26") end_date <- as.Date("2022/11/27")  # Daily day_seq <-   seq.Date(     from = start_date,     to = end_date,     by = "day"   )  identify_datefreq(day_seq) #> [1] "monthly"  # Weekly week_seq <-   seq.Date(     from = start_date,     to = end_date,     by = "week"   )  identify_datefreq(week_seq) #> [1] "monthly"  # Monthly month_seq <-   seq.Date(     from = start_date,     to = end_date,     by = "month"   ) identify_datefreq(month_seq) #> [1] "monthly"

what: Identify whether a habitual behaviour exists over a given interval of time — identify_habit
title: Identify whether a habitual behaviour exists over a given interval of time — identify_habit
text: Based principle consistency, function identifies whether habit exists given interval time. habit defined behaviour (action taken) repeated least x number times consistently n weeks.

title: Identify whether a habitual behaviour exists over a given interval of time — identify_habit
code: identify_habit(   data,   metric,   threshold = 1,   width,   max_window,   hrvar = NULL,   return = "plot",   plot_mode = "time",   fill_col = c("#E5E5E5", "#0078D4") )

title: Identify whether a habitual behaviour exists over a given interval of time — identify_habit
text: data Data frame containing Person Query analysed. data frame must PersonId, MetricDate column containing metric classifying behaviour. metric Character string specifying metric analysed. threshold Numeric value specifying minimum number times metric sum order valid count. 'greater equal ' logic used. width Integer specifying number qualifying counts consider habit. function assumes weekly interval used. max_window Integer specifying maximum unit dates consider qualifying window habit. data grouped weekly level, max_window = 12 consider 12 weeks. hrvar Character string specifying HR attribute organisational variable group . Default NULL. return Character string specifying type output returned. Valid options include: "data": Returns data frame habit classification. "plot": Returns ggplot object boxplot, showing percentage periods habitual behaviour occurred. "summary": Returns summary table habit analysis. plot_mode Character string specifying type plot returned. applicable return = "plot". Valid options include: "time": Returns time series plot breakdown users habitual behaviour. "boxplot": Returns boxplot percentage periods habitual behaviour. fill_col Character vector length 2 specifying colours used plot. applicable return = "plot" plot_mode = "time".

title: Identify whether a habitual behaviour exists over a given interval of time — identify_habit
text: week considered binary variable whether sufficient action taken given week (qualifying count). Sufficiency determined threshold parameter. instance, threshold set 2, means must 2 qualifying actions (e.g. summarise meeting Copilot) week qualifying count week. One way determining parameters consider, many counts width occur within max_window period considered habit?

title: Identify whether a habitual behaviour exists over a given interval of time — identify_habit
code: # Return a plot identify_habit(   pq_data,   metric = "Multitasking_hours",   threshold = 1,   width = 9,   max_window = 12,   return = "plot" )   # Return a summary identify_habit(   pq_data,   metric = "Multitasking_hours",   threshold = 1,   width = 9,   max_window = 12,   return = "summary" ) #> # A tibble: 21 × 2 #>    Statistics                                    Value #>    <chr>                                         <dbl> #>  1 Most recent week - Total persons with habit 218     #>  2 Most recent week - % of pop with habit        0.727 #>  3 Total Persons who have lost habit           128     #>  4 % of Persons who have lost habit              0.427 #>  5 Total Persons who have gained habit         287     #>  6 % of Persons who have gained habit            0.957 #>  7 Mean - % of Person-weeks with habit           0.405 #>  8 Min - % of Person-weeks with habit            0     #>  9 p10                                           0.126 #> 10 p25                                           0.293 #> # ℹ 11 more rows
